title: Esophageal Carcinoma
diagnosis_topic: Locally advanced esophageal adenocarcinoma requiring multimodal therapy and surgical management
setup_script: “A 60-year-old man with a history of long-term smoking and alcohol use presents with progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and now to liquids. He has lost 15 pounds over the past 3 months. On physical exam, he appears thin and somewhat cachectic. Vital signs are stable, and abdominal exam is benign. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders initial workup with endoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Upper endoscopy reveals a circumferential mass in the distal third of the esophagus. Biopsies confirm adenocarcinoma.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests staging with EUS and CT/PET
dynamic_flow.reply: “Endoscopic ultrasound shows a T3 lesion with suspected periesophageal nodes. PET/CT shows no evidence of distant metastasis.”
“BMI is 19 kg/m², serum albumin 3.0 g/dL. Patient reports difficulty maintaining oral intake. What would you consider next?”
“Feeding jejunostomy is placed laparoscopically, and patient is optimized nutritionally before therapy.”
“Patient receives 5 weeks of carboplatin/paclitaxel with concurrent radiotherapy (CROSS regimen). He tolerates treatment well.”
“Restaging PET/CT shows stable disease without metastasis; primary tumor appears decreased in thickness.”
“Patient undergoes transthoracic (Ivor Lewis) esophagectomy with gastric pull-up and two-field lymphadenectomy. Please describe your operative steps.”

“Abdominal phase: mobilization of the stomach with preservation of right gastroepiploic artery, division of left gastric artery, creation of gastric conduit. Thoracic phase: right thoracotomy, en bloc esophagectomy, mediastinal lymphadenectomy, esophagogastric anastomosis in the chest. What are potential intraoperative complications?”
“Risks include injury to thoracic duct (chyle leak), recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, bleeding, and gastric conduit ischemia.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative course
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient is admitted to ICU, extubated on day 1, started on jejunal feeds. On POD 5, he develops tachycardia and fever. What would you do?”
“CT chest shows peri-anastomotic collection with air and contrast leak.”
“Patient undergoes endoscopic stent placement and drainage; he gradually improves. What is your long-term follow-up plan?”
“CT and endoscopy every 6 months for 2 years, then annually; nutritional monitoring and lifestyle modification including smoking/alcohol cessation.”

critical_decision_points: Appropriate diagnostic workup including endoscopy, biopsy, staging with EUS and PET/CT
Nutritional assessment and support prior to therapy
Neoadjuvant chemoradiation for locally advanced disease
Surgical planning: Ivor Lewis esophagectomy, gastric conduit creation, lymphadenectomy
Recognition and management of perioperative complications (leak, chyle leak, pneumonia)
